title: Rewriting the Base
text: The first step is to rewrite the equation so that both sides have a common base. Since $$8$$ and $$16$$ are both powers of $$2$$, we can use $$2$$ as a common base.

title: Rewriting the Base
text: Rewriting both sides into expressions with a base of $$2$$, we get $$2^{3\left(x+2\right)}=2^{4\left(x+1\right)}$$

title: One-To-One Property of Exponential Functions
text: For any algebraic expressions s and $$t$$, and any positive real number $$b$$ that is not equal to $$1$$, $$b^s=b^t$$ if and only if $$s=t$$.

title: Appylying the One-To-Property to the Problem
text: Both expressions have a base of $$2$$, so using the property, we see that $$3\left(x+2\right)=4\left(x+1\right)$$. This simplifies to $$3x+6=4x+4$$.
